awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Investigation of strain and superior functionalization schemes for large enhancement of thermal conductivity in polymer-graphene nanocomposites and binary semiconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
High thermal conductivity polymers and semiconductors hold potential to significantly improve thermal management in wide range of applications including electronics, automobiles, aerospace, power generation and energy harvesting.  The research objective of this project is to investigate ways to significantly enhance thermal conductivity of polymer-semiconductor composite materials, through superior bonding between polymer and graphene with higher interfacial thermal transport and by controlling orientation of polymer chains and graphene nanoplatelets. The educational objectives of the project are to engage high school students through a summer camp program. To stimulate fascination with thermal transport, high school students will measure thermal response in different nanocomposites through colorful visualization of temperatures maps using infra-red imaging. Simultaneously the program will aim to enhance diversity by engaging Native American students from various tribal colleges in Oklahoma. The participants will develop understanding of both atomistic simulations and also perform experimental characterization of thermal transport.
 
Within polymers, thermal conductivity is highest along the polymer chain axis. Simultaneous alignment of polymer chains and planar direction of nanoplatelets, to conduct heat along the most efficient directions in the two components, is achieved in this project through strain. Alignment is characterized through microscopy and imaging. Non-equilibrium Green?s function technique has been used to reveal covalent bonding schemes enabling superior phonon transmission between polymer and graphene. Functionalized polymer composites prepared through such schemes are thermally characterized in this work through both experiments and atomistic simulations. Energy gap in the vibrational spectra of semiconductors has been shown to suppress scattering of low energy phonons, leading to large enhancement in their lifetimes, and overall material thermal conductivity. Strain can further increase energy gap, resulting in higher phonon lifetimes. Strain effects are quantified in this project by deriving interatomic force interactions from density-functional theory and using them with an exact solution of the phonon Boltzmann transport equation to predict thermal conductivity. Design of next generation high thermal conductivity polymers and semiconductors will lead to high impact opportunities for improving thermal management in a wide array of technologies.  This award is jointly funded by the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems in the Directorate of Engineering and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research in the Office of Integrative Activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on design and synthesis of high thermal conductivity polymer-graphene nanocomposites as well as design of high thermal conductivity semiconductors. Thermal conductivity of polymer-graphene composites was enhanced through two key effects – a) by aligning the high thermal conductivity directions of polymer and graphene through application of strain. Within polymers, high thermal conductivity is along the chain length, while in graphene thermal conductivity is high along the in-plane direction. b) by enhancing interfacial thermal transport  between polymer and graphene through the superior edge functionalization of graphene, as compared to basal plane functionalization. Edge functionalization offers several distinct advantages over basal plane functionalization. Edge functionalization preserves the high thermal conductivity of the basal plane, while basal plane functionalization leads to a dramatic reduction in thermal conductivity of graphene. For graphene nanoplatelets with multiple graphene sheets,  basal plane functionalization couples outermost layers with polymer, which in turn have poor thermal transport to inner layers through weak van der Waals forces. Edge functionalization, however, couples all graphene layers (within a nanoplatelet) to the surrounding polymer, leading to superior enhancement in thermal transport.

            The project simultaneously, focused on investigating the effect of strain on enhancement of thermal conductivity of semiconductors, through manipulation of a phononic band gap between acoustic and optical phonons. Phonon band gap between acoustic and optical phonons, suppresses scattering of acoustic phonons by optical phonons, leading to significant enhancement in thermal conductivity. Strain can be used to engineer the band gap, providing new avenues to engineer thermal conductivity of semiconductor materials.

Outcomes of the research activities are summarized below.

1. Simultaneous alignment of polymer lamellae and graphene nanoplatelets was used to achieve a thermal conductivity enhancement of nearly 1200% [Nanomaterials 10, 1291 (2020)] over the thermal conductivity of pristine polyethylene (0.5 W/mK). At a draw ratio of nearly 5 and with 10 wt% graphene nanoplatelets, an in-plane thermal conductivity of nearly 7 W/mK was achieved. To achieve above results, polyethylene-graphene nanocomposites were prepared by mixing polyethylene and graphene nanoplatelets (lateral size ~ 5 mm, thickness ~ 60 nm) in a microcompounder. The prepared nanocomposites were then stretched to different draw ratios using a tensile transducer. The stretching of the composite induced simultaneous alignment of polymer lamellae and planar surface of graphene nanoplatelets. The degree of alignment of polymer chains was characterized by wide angle X-ray scattering (WAXS). Alignment of graphene nanoplatelets was confirmed by confocal laser scanning microscopy. In-plane thermal conductivity of strained composites was measured using Angstrom method. The results provide new avenues to achieve high thermal conductivity polymer composites through alignment effects.

2. Edge oxidized graphene (EGO) nanoplatelets were demonstrated to lead to enhancement of thermal conductivity of polyetherimide-graphene nanocomposites, while basal plane oxidized (BGO) nanoplatelets were found to lead to even lower thermal conductivity than pristine-graphene/polyetherimide composites [ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 14, 14753-14763 (2022)], clearly demonstrating the advantage of edge functionalization in enabling high thermal conductivity polymer-graphene nanocomposites. Edge oxidation of graphene nanoplatelets was achieved through a modified oxidation scheme involving oxidizing graphene using sulfuric acid and sodium chlorate. The method introduced an excess of carboxylic acid groups on edges of graphene nanoplatelets. Basal plane oxidation was achieved by Hummer’s method. Oxidation of the basal plane also resulted in exfoliation of graphene nanoplatelets into thinner sheets. Detailed characterization of edge and basal plane oxidation was performed. Raman spectroscopy was performed to measure ID/IG ratio of edge and basal plane oxidized graphene nanoplatelets. The ratio on the basal plane of EGO was found to be only 0.26, while the ratio on the basal plane for BGO was measured to be around 0.90, clearly suggesting preferential oxidation of edge of graphene for EGO, and preferential oxidation of basal plane for BGO. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS),  Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) analysis and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were also used to establish edge and basal plane oxidation of graphene nanoplatelets.

3. Nanoscale thermal conductivity of Boron Phosphide was demonstrated to be enhanced through application of strain [Phys. Chem. Phys. 22, 20914, 2020]. First-principles computations were used to demonstrate that biaxial strain enhanced nanoscale k of boron phosphide to values even higher than the bulk k value of silicon.  At a length scale of L = 200 nm, k of 4% biaxially strained BP was enhanced by 25% to a value of 150.4 W m−1 K−1, relative to 120 W m−1 K−1 computed for unstrained BP at 300 K. Application of strain increased phonon band gap between acoustic and optical phonons. This suppressed anharmonic scattering of acoustic phonons (by optical phonons) in the higher frequency range where phonon mean freepaths are in the nanometer range, leading to an increase in nanoscale k. Computations were performed by deriving harmonic and anharmonic interatomic force constants from density-functional theory and using them in an exact solution of phonon Boltzmann equation.
